add.description-tooltip: This value can be used e.g. on the consent screen.
add.displayName-tooltip: This value can be used e.g. on the consent screen.
add.enabled-tooltip: Indicates if this resource is enabled and can be requested. Defaults to true.
add.name: Name
add.name-tooltip: The unique name of the API. This value is used for authentication with introspection and will be added to the audience of the outgoing access token.
add.userClaims-tooltip: List of associated user claim types that should be included in the access token.

apiResource.description: Resources are something you want to protect with IdentityServer – either APIs (by doing this your data will be protected as well). So to access your database content must be through an API.

edit.description-tooltip: This value can be used e.g. on the consent screen.
edit.displayName-tooltip: This value can be used e.g. on the consent screen.
edit.enabled-tooltip: Indicates if this resource is enabled and can be requested. Defaults to true.
edit.name: Name
edit.name-tooltip: The unique name of the API. This value is used for authentication with introspection and will be added to the audience of the outgoing access token.
edit.scope-tooltip: An API must have at least one scope. Each scope can have different settings.
edit.secrets-tooltip: The API secret is used for the introspection endpoint. The API can authenticate with introspection using the API name and secret.
edit.userClaims-tooltip: List of associated user claim types that should be included in the access token.

remove.title: Are you sure

scope.Emphasize-tooltip: Specifies whether the consent screen will emphasize this scope (if the consent screen wants to implement such a feature). Use this setting for sensitive or important scopes. Defaults to false.
scope.description-tooltip: This value can be used e.g. on the consent screen.
scope.displayName-tooltip: This value can be used e.g. on the consent screen.
scope.name: Name
scope.name-tooltip: The unique name of the API. This value is used for authentication with introspection and will be added to the audience of the outgoing access token.
scope.required-tooltip: Specifies whether the user can de-select the scope on the consent screen. Defaults to false.
scope.showInDiscoveryDocument-tooltip: Specifies whether this scope is shown in the discovery document. Defaults to true
scope.userClaims-tooltip: List of associated user claim types that should be included in the access token.

apiResource.secret-description: The API secret is used for the introspection endpoint. The API can authenticate with introspection using the API name and secret.

client.ClaimDescription: Allows settings claims for the client (will be included in the access token)
client.ClientDescription: The Client class represents an OpenID Connect or OAuth 2.0 client - e.g. a native application, a web application or a JS-based application
client.PropertiesDescription: Dictionary to hold any custom client-specific values as needed
client.SecretDescription:
In certain situations, clients need to authenticate with identityserver, e.g.:
1- confidential applications (aka clients) requesting tokens at the token endpoint.
2- APIs validating reference tokens at the introspection endpoint

details.absoluteRefreshTokenLifetime-tooltip: Maximum lifetime of a refresh token in seconds. Defaults to 2592000 seconds / 30 days
details.accessTokenLifetime-tooltip: Lifetime of access token in seconds (defaults to 3600 seconds / 1 hour)
details.accessTokenTypes-tooltip: Specifies whether the access token is a reference token or a self contained JWT token (defaults to Jwt)
details.allowAccessTokensViaBrowser-tooltip: Specifies whether this client is allowed to receive access tokens via the browser. This is useful to harden flows that allow multiple response types (e.g. by disallowing a hybrid flow client that is supposed to use code id_token to add the token response type and thus leaking the token to the browser.
details.allowOfflineAccess-tooltip: Specifies whether this client can request refresh tokens (be requesting the offline_access scope)
details.allowPlainTextPkce-tooltip: Specifies whether clients using PKCE can use a plain text code challenge (not recommended - and default to false)
details.allowRememberConsent-tooltip: Specifies whether user can choose to store consent decisions. Defaults to true.
details.allowedCorsOrigins-tooltip: If specified, will be used by the default CORS policy service implementations (In-Memory and EF) to build a CORS policy for JavaScript clients.
details.allowedGrantTypes-tooltip: Specifies the grant types the client is allowed to use. Use the GrantTypes class for common combinations. List of default grants: Implicit Grant - (implicit), Client Credentials Grant - (client_credentials), Authorization Code Grant - (authorization_code), Hybrid grant - (hybrid), Resource Owner Password Credentials Grant - (password)
details.allowedScopes-tooltip: By default a client has no access to any resources - specify the allowed resources by adding the corresponding scopes names
details.alwaysIncludeUserClaimsInIdToken: Always Include User Claims In IdToken
details.alwaysIncludeUserClaimsInIdToken-tooltip: When requesting both an id token and access token, should the user claims always be added to the id token instead of requring the client to use the userinfo endpoint. Default is false
details.alwaysSendClientClaims-tooltip: If set, the client claims will be sent for every flow. If not, only for client credentials flow (default is false)
details.authorizationCodeLifetime-tooltip: Lifetime of authorization code in seconds (defaults to 300 seconds / 5 minutes)
details.backChannelLogoutSessionRequired-tooltip: Specifies if the user’s session id should be sent in the request to the BackChannelLogoutUri. Defaults to true
details.backChannelLogoutUri-tooltip: Specifies logout URI at client for HTTP based back-channel logout. See the OIDC Back-Channel spec for more details
details.claims-tooltip: Allows settings claims for the client (will be included in the access token)
details.clientClaimsPrefix-tooltip: If set, the prefix client claim types will be prefixed with. Defaults to client_. The intent is to make sure they don’t accidentally collide with user claims.
details.clientSecrets-tooltip: List of client secrets - credentials to access the token endpoint.
details.clientUri-tooltip: URI to further information about client (used on consent screen)
details.deviceCodeLifetime-tooltip: Lifetime to device code in seconds (defaults to 300 seconds / 5 minutes)
details.enabled-tooltip: Specifies if client is enabled. Defaults to true.
details.frontChannelLogoutSessionRequired-toolti: Specifies if the user’s session id should be sent to the FrontChannelLogoutUri. Defaults to true
details.frontChannelLogoutUri-tooltip: Specifies logout URI at client for HTTP based front-channel logout. See the OIDC Front-Channel spec for more details
details.identityProviderRestrictions-tooltip: Specifies which external IdPs can be used with this client (if list is empty all IdPs are allowed). Defaults to empty.
details.identityTokenLifetime-tooltip: Lifetime to identity token in seconds (defaults to 300 seconds / 5 minutes)
details.includeJwtId-tooltip: Specifies whether JWT access tokens should have an embedded unique ID (via the jti claim).
details.logoUri-tooltip: URI to client logo (used on consent screen). Must be Https
details.name: Name
details.name-tooltip: Client display name (used for logging and consent screen)
details.pairWiseSubjectSalt-tooltip: Salt value used in pair-wise subjectId generation for users of this client.
details.properties-tooltip: Dictionary to hold any custom client-specific values as needed.
details.redirectUris-tooltip: Specifies the allowed URIs to return tokens or authorization codes to
details.refreshTokenExpiration-tooltip: Absolute the refresh token will expire on a fixed point in time (specified by the AbsoluteRefreshTokenLifetime) Sliding when refreshing the token, the lifetime of the refresh token will be renewed (by the amount specified in SlidingRefreshTokenLifetime). The lifetime will not exceed AbsoluteRefreshTokenLifetime.
details.refreshTokenUsage-tooltip: ReUse the refresh token handle will stay the same when refreshing tokens OneTime the refresh token handle will be updated when refreshing tokens
details.requireClientSecret-tooltip: Specifies whether this client needs a secret to request tokens from the token endpoint (defaults to true)
details.requireConsent-tooltip: Specifies whether a consent screen is required. Defaults to true.
details.requirePkce-tooltip: Specifies whether clients using an authorization code based grant type must send a proof key
details.slidingRefreshTokenLifetime-tooltip: Sliding lifetime of a refresh token in seconds. Defaults to 1296000 seconds / 15 days
details.updateAccessTokenClaimsOnRefresh: Update Access Token Claims On Refresh
details.updateAccessTokenClaimsOnRefresh-tooltip: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the access token (and its claims) should be updated on a refresh token request
details.userCodeType-tooltip: Specifies the type of user code to use for the client. Otherwise falls back to default
details.postLogoutRedirectUris-tooltip: Specifies allowed URIs to redirect to after logout
details.enableLocalLogin-tooltip: Specifies if this client can use local accounts, or external Providers only. E.g: Facebook, Google. Defaults to true
details.userSsoLifetime-tooltip: The maximum duration (in seconds) since the last time the user authenticated. Defaults to null. You can adjust the lifetime of a session token to control when and how often a user is required to reenter credentials instead of being silently authenticated, when using a web application

home.DESCRIPTION: This is IdentityServer4 Admin Panel. Here you can manage your IS4 settings.

add.description-tooltip: This value will be used e.g. on the consent screen.
add.displayName-tooltip: This value will be used e.g. on the consent screen.
add.emphasize-tooltip: Specifies whether the consent screen will emphasize this scope (if the consent screen wants to implement such a feature). Use this setting for sensitive or important scopes. Defaults to false.
add.enabled-tooltip: Indicates if this resource is enabled and can be requested. Defaults to true.
add.name: Name
add.name-tooltip: The unique name of the identity resource. This is the value a client will use for the scope parameter in the authorize request.
add.required-tooltip: Specifies whether the user can de-select the scope on the consent screen (if the consent screen wants to implement such a feature). Defaults to false.
add.showInDiscoveryDocument-tooltip: Specifies whether this scope is shown in the discovery document. Defaults to true.
add.userClaims-tooltip: List of associated user claim types that should be included in the identity token.

identityResource.description: Identity resources are data like user ID, name, or email address of a user. An identity resource has a unique name, and you can assign arbitrary claim types to it. These claims will then be included in the identity token for the user.

edit.description-tooltip: This value will be used e.g. on the consent screen.
edit.displayName-tooltip: This value will be used e.g. on the consent screen.
edit.emphasize-tooltip: Specifies whether the consent screen will emphasize this scope (if the consent screen wants to implement such a feature). Use this setting for sensitive or important scopes. Defaults to false.
edit.enabled-tooltip: Indicates if this resource is enabled and can be requested. Defaults to true.
edit.name: Name
edit.name-tooltip: The unique name of the identity resource. This is the value a client will use for the scope parameter in the authorize request.
edit.required-tooltip: Specifies whether the user can de-select the scope on the consent screen (if the consent screen wants to implement such a feature). Defaults to false.
edit.showInDiscoveryDocument-tooltip: Specifies whether this scope is shown in the discovery document. Defaults to true.
edit.userClaims-tooltip: List of associated user claim types that should be included in the identity token.

add.roleName-tooltip: Gets or sets the role name.

roles.description: Represents a role in the identity system

edit.roleName-tooltip: Gets or sets the role name.

roles.name: Name

secrets.hashType-tooltip: Set the hash of Secret Value
secrets.secretType-tooltip: The type of the client secret

users.description: A user is a person or robot that can access resources and clients.

edit.accessFailedCount-tooltip: Gets or sets the number of failed login attempts for the current user
edit.claims-tooltip: Allows settings claims for the user (will be included in the access token)
edit.email-tooltip: Gets or sets the email address for this user
edit.emailConfirmed-tooltip: Gets or sets a flag indicating if a user has confirmed their email address
edit.externalLogins-tooltip: Manage user external login. e.g Google, Facebook
edit.lockoutEnabled-tooltip: Gets or sets a flag indicating if the user could be locked out
edit.lockoutEnd-tooltip: Gets or sets the date and time, in UTC, when any user lockout ends
edit.name: Display Name
edit.name-tooltip: Gets or sets the user name
edit.phoneNumber-tooltip: Gets or sets a telephone number for the user
edit.phoneNumberConfirmed-tooltip: Gets or sets a flag indicating if a user has confirmed their telephone address
edit.roles-tooltip: Allows settings roles for the user (will be included in the access token)
edit.twoFactorEnabled-tooltip: Gets or sets a flag indicating if two factor authentication is enabled for this user
edit.userName-tooltip: Gets or sets the user name for this user.
edit.confirmEmail-tooltip: This user should confirm his e-mail
edit.socialNumber-tooltip: SSN for Users. EID in case of company user

remove.text: Your will not be able to recover!
remove.title: Are you sure

edit.type-tooltip: Type of communication with the user
edit.subject: Subject
edit.bcc-tooltip: Blind Carbon Copy - Blind copy someone
edit.senderName-tooltip: The name of who will send the e-mail.
edit.senderAddress-tooltip: Address from who will send the e-mail
edit.variables-description: A list of variables which will be replaced before send to User.
edit.variables-code: Generated code for user for him confirm E-mail
edit.variables-provider: When user are using Federation login. It'll be the provider name (E.G: Google | Facebook)
edit.variables-url: Unique url generate for user to confirm e-mail

settings.description: Global settings to manage your SSO configuration

storage.description: Storage Settings for profile images, client images and any kind of SSO file.
storage.local-description: Storage will be the same folder of SSO filesystem
storage.virtualPath-tooltip: Virtual Path to concatenate with Base Path

recaptcha.site-key-tooltip: Site key is used in HTML
recaptcha.private-key-tooltip: Secret key is for communication between API and reCAPTCHA
recaptcha.useRecaptcha-tooltip: If enabled it will be used in some flows

ldap.description: Lightweight Directory Access Protocol is an open, vendor-neutral, industry standard application protocol for accessing and maintaining distributed directory information services over an Internet Protocol (IP) network
ldap.domainName-tooltip: The server ID. A string specifying the domain name
ldap.distinguishedName-tooltip: A name that includes an object's entire path to the root of the LDAP namespace is called its distinguished name, or DN.
ldap.authType-tooltip: Used to specify the authentication method to use on a connection
ldap.attributes-tooltip: Attributes are the elements responsible for storing data in a directory
ldap.searchScope-tooltip: Specifies the scope of a search
ldap.useLdap-tooltip: Set SSO to use LDAP instead ASP.NET Identity
ldap.connectionless-tooltip: TRUE if the connection is UDP or FALSE if the connection uses TCP/IP
ldap.fullyQualifiedDomainName-tooltip: TRUE if each element in servers is a fully-qualified DNS host name. If FALSE an element can be an IP address, a DNS domain or host name
ldap.portNumber-tooltip: The port number to be used when connecting to the server
ldap.address-tooltip: The address of LDAP server name or dotted strings representing the IP address of the LDAP server.

events.description: Search for generated events from SSO

validations.notEqualToPassword: The new password should be different from actual.
